rounds.response:
I’m now finally the one who has to act post-flop.  
Position: Small-blind / out of position.  
Stack: 890 chips.  
Pot: 30.  
Current bet to me: 20 chips.  
My hand: 6♦ K♠ — “King-high with a 6 kicker” off-suit.

Opponent has been very aggressive: he 4-bet to 80 then fired an 80-chip continuation-bet into the 6-2-2 rainbow flop in the last hand, winning the 240-chip pot when I folded K♥ 7♥. That alone makes his range wide—he’s capable of big sizes with air.

King-high on an uncoordinated low flop is ordinarily ahead of much of a wide 3-bet range (all unpaired holdings like Q-J suited, A-5 suited, etc. whiffed here) but behind anything that contains a 2, 6, a pocket pair 77-JJ, or any over-pairs that slow-played pre-flop. Given the pot odds (20 to win 50 at this step), folding is slightly too nitty; raising is risky out of position with only king-high kicker. Leading into the aggressor here by calling keeps the pot small and allows us to realize equity when we hit a king on later streets, while respecting the chance villain hit a 2.

Therefore:

[Call]
